chapter.para: The Rackspace &CImS; enables developers to create and manipulate images, image members, and associated metadata through a simple Representational State Transfer (REST) web service interface.

The
Rackspace Cloud Images Developer Guide provides detailed information about how to use the &CImA; v2, and this guide provides some easy steps to get started using images.

The
Cloud Images FAQ in the Knowledge Center provides more information about the &CImS;.
This chapter describes what images are, how you share images with others, and how you use asynchronous image tasks.

section.title: Images
section.para: Server images are used to store a snapshot of a server's configuration. If you take an image of a server, you can create a new server from that image. The new server will have the same files and operating system that the original server had at the time the image was created.
The &CImS; provides operations that enable you to manipulate images, to import and export images (by using tasks), and to share images with other people.

To learn how to use an existing image, see "POST_importImage_tasks_Image_Task_Calls"
Section 4.4.3. "Task to Import Image" in the Cloud Images Developer Guide.

The &CImS; enables you to use standard images (which are supported by Rackspace) and to create, share, and use nonstandard images (which are not supported by Rackspace). For more information, see
Rackspace Standard and Non-Standard Images at http://www.rackspace.com/knowledge_center/article/rackspace-standard-and-non-standard-images.

section.title: Statuses
section.para: The &CImA; uses a variety of statuses to identify the state of images or image components. This section describes the statuses and their values.

section.title: Image statuses
section.para: Images in the &CImS; can have any of the following statuses when you display details by using the instructions in "GET_getImage_images__image_id__Image_Calls" “Get details for an image”.

listitem.para: The image identifier has been reserved for an image in the Cloud Images registry. No image data has been uploaded to the &CImS;, and the image size was not explicitly set to zero on creation.
An image's raw data is being uploaded to the &CImS;.
The image is fully available in the &CImS;. This status applies either after the image is uploaded or if the image size is explicitly set to zero on creation.
An error occurred during the image upload process, and the image data is unreadable.
The &CImS; has retained the information about the image, but the image is no longer available to use. An image with this status will be removed automatically at a later date.
This status is similar to deleted, however, the &CImS; has not yet removed the image data. An image with this status is recoverable.

The administrator has marked the image as unavailable while it is under investigation. Image operations like list, get details, image sharing, and set metadata work, however, users cannot perform operations that must access image data. For example, users cannot boot from a deactivated image or export a deactivated image.

section.title: Task statuses
section.para: Image tasks are used for importing images from your Cloud Files account and for exporting images to your Cloud files account. For more information on image tasks, see “Asynchronous image tasks”“Asynchronous image tasks”.
Image tasks in the &CImS; can have any of the following statuses when you poll them by using instructions in "GET_getTask_tasks__taskID__Image_Task_Calls" “Get details for a task”.

listitem.para: The image task is waiting for execution.
The image task is processing.
The image task completed successfully.
The image task did not complete successfully.

section.title: Image member statuses
section.para: When an image producer wants to share an image with a potential image consumer, the producer creates an image member, linking the image and the consumer. Once an image is shared, the image is available for the consumer to use, regardless of image member status. Both producers and consumers can check the status of an image member.

Image member status both controls whether the image appears in the consumer's image list and lets the producer know whether the consumer acknowledges the offer. If the consumer wants the image to appear in the image list, the consumer accepts the image. Otherwise, the consumer rejects the image.

If the image producer no longer wants the share an image with a consumer, the producer deletes the image member. Once the image member is deleted, the consumer cannot use the image, and the image is removed from the consumer's image list.
For more information on image sharing, see “Image sharing”“Image sharing”.

listitem.para: Consumers and producers view the image status by using the instructions in "GET_getImageMember_images__image_id__members__member_id__Image_Both_Calls" “Get image member details”
Consumers change the status any time by using the instructions in "PUT_updateImageMember_images__image_id__members__member_id__Image_Consumer_Calls"“Update an image member”
Producers add image members by using the instructions in "POST_createImageMember_images__image_id__members_Image_Producer_Calls"“Create an image member”
Producers delete image members by using the instructions in "DELETE_deleteImageMember_images__image_id__members__member_id__Image_Producer_Calls" >“Delete an image member”

section.para: Image members can have any of the following statuses.

listitem.para: The consumer accepts the invitation to potentially use the offered image, and the image appears in the consumer's image list. The producer knows that the consumer made an active decision about the image.

The consumer declines the invitation to potentially use the offered image, and the image does not appears in the consumer's image list. The producer knows that the consumer made an active decision about the image.
The consumer can still use the image, but must know the image ID, since the image is not in the image list.

The consumer neither accepts nor declines the invitation to potentially use the offered image, and may not have even noticed the offer. The producer might elect to send a reminder that the image is available, but this is outside the scope of the &CImA;.
The consumer can still use the image, but must know the image ID, since the image is not in the image list.
